me.message: Since my trip to Cape Town in May, I have resolved to write more frequently. I love writing, sharing with others, and telling stories, but had never really maximized these passions. The philosophy of "Diving In" I learned and honed during my time in South Africa led me to the conclusion that I just had to take action and immerse myself in my writing. Throughout our lives, we will all take leaps of varying sizes. So I wanted to share some things I have learned that hopefully will give you all the confidence to take those risks and bet on yourself.

me.message:
Marco Madness is back. In one month and one day, Marco and the rest of Delta Chi will walk the tunnel at the Crisler Center, ready to fight cancer once again. While we congregate annually to have this battle, Marco does it every day and that is what makes it so special. This is not merely a fundraiser, but also a celebration of Marco and the obstacles he has continually overcome. Living two doors down from him this year has been an honor and a privilege. With a contagious passion for his brothers and life as a whole, having him back in the house has been the capstone of my Delta Chi experience this year. Fellow wolverines, family, and friends, I hope you can find it in your heart to contribute to our battle. Whether it's 5 dollars, 50 dollars, or 500, you are helping Marco, his family, the brothers of Delta Chi, and, most importantly, all many children who fight pediatric cancer. 
Expect many more posts like this over the course of the month. 
We at Delta Chi wish you the happiest of holidays and new years, and hope that you can fit Marco Madness into your 2017 plans.
A very Swagler Christmas

I will not salute Ohio State. They did not deserve to win. The officiating crew should be ashamed of themselves, and I hope they look back and realize they negative impact they have had on the sport of football. 

I am so proud of this Michigan team. Sure, we had some missed opportunities today, but I have never seen a team be transformed by a coach like Michigan under Jim Harbaugh's control. He has brought back the Michigan football that had been known and loved for generations, and the love and respect he has received reflects that. 

I am proud to be a Michigan Wolverine, and wish the worst for The Ohio State and all of its constituents. 
(If you couldn't tell I'm pretty upset)

me.message:
It's crazy to think that this is my second 9/11 away from the NYC community. It's even crazier to think that it has been 15 years since that tragic and surreal day. New Yorkers around my age share a lot of the memories I have; brief, naive observations of the TV and, perhaps, a view of the WTC itself, parents and other relatives crying and looking fearful, fathers and mothers rushing home to their families, and parents shielding our eyes from the harsh and hateful reality. Along with most New Yorkers, I know (way too) many people that lost someone 15 years ago. To those people: I love you all. Be strong. You are all warriors.
There is no community that I am more proud of than the one I have in NYC. There is no community that I know that is more resilient. In spite of all responsibilities and self-interest, we are of city of one on  9/11. We are a diverse, unique, and brilliant 8 million person family, and no amount of hatred or fear can change that. 
Never forget.

me.message:
Thank you Luis LoudMouth Camacho for the nomination.
I know this is just the next social media fad, but given the cause I had to oblige.
22 veterans commit suicide every day. That is a staggering statistic. 
While we claim to support our troops, there needs to be more attention paid to our vets, who may well come out physically, mentally, and emotionally scarred. That sacrifice is often made without ample attention or treatment.

me.message: As philanthropy chair of a fraternity that raised almost $50,000 last year for cancer research and autism awareness, I can't help but challenge the premise of this policy, which is essentially discouraging leadership in areas that Harvard feels isolates the privileged and excludes the less fortunate. Not only does Harvard's elitist history lead to a contradiction, but they are also neglecting the governing values of many fraternities on their campus and throughout the nation. If one looks past the stigmatized notion of social stratification, they will often find a deep background in community engagement and public service. Same sex organizations will exist. Same sex sports will be played. That is the purpose of an affinity group: to be a part of a group of like-minded individuals with similar goals and ideas (This doesn't mean fraternities members are the SAME. Everyone has a story). There is no end all be all way to define diversity, and writing these social constructs off as exclusive and discriminatory doesn't account for all of the great things that happen within them. Keeping an open mind goes both ways. Leaders within the the Harvard Greek community will be hindered by these policies. The perceived 'top' is being pushed down, when many of its members are seeking to make a positive difference and to give back.

me.message: While I have my issues with Hillary, this is the problem the media's influence on modern politics. While my friends post this all over Facebook thinking that it is "funny" or "appalling", all I can think about is how much doing that exacerbates the personalization bias in the media. Who cares if she takes the subway? If you were the secretary of state and worth millions of dollars, you might not take the subway either. This is a classic example of how the Sanders team and my generation frame Hillary as elitist, inadequately fluent in pop culture, and ingenuine. While this video is funny on the surface, it really isn't, because hitting share and tagging all of your friends is worsening the already existing problems with the media. This stoops just as low as Trump does, because it takes advantage of the malleable positions of moderately politically educated millenials like myself. I've definitely fallen victim to the influence of silly stuff like this, but I just know this one is bullshit.

Hi, Everyone! As co-philanthropy chair of Delta Chi along with my good friend Justin Kaplan, we are EXTREMELY excited to finally announce our upcoming event to support another good friend of ours, Marco Gutierrez in his battle against leukemia. We've worked extremely hard to make this as dope as possible. Looking forward to everybody enjoying the madness, supporting Marco, and ballin out #marcostrong
Here some info about the event:
Marco Madness is raising money for treating pediatric leukemia through the Children’s National Medical Center in Washington D.C. Children’s National is currently the only health system designed for kids in the Washington D.C. metropolitan area.With your help, and donations, we can help fund the fight against pediatric leukemia. This philanthropy event honors Marco Gutierrez, a freshmen at the University of Michigan, who was forced to leave school shortly after arriving due to the remission of his Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia. Marco courageously fought through treatment of A.L.L. for three years of his life in high school prior to coming to Michigan. He currently is at home fighting hard to recover so that he can return to Michigan in the fall. Marco is a loving, caring, courageous, and truly inspirational friend and individual. We want to support Marco to beat his leukemia like the first time, as well as support everyone else who suffers from these horrible diseases.

Earlier this week, my good friend, and future fraternity brother, Marco, revealed to our entire pledge class that he had struggled with Leukemia throughout high school. He fought like no other, and got into, in my opinion, the best school on the planet. Without even knowing him for that long, I can honestly say that he is one of the toughest kids I know. Friends, family, and fellow Michigan students, I ask that you take a moment (and maybe a few dollars), and invest some effort in making a difference. Help Marco, and millions of others suffering from cancer, by showing your support. Anything would be greatly appreciated.

me.message: For the first time since I left, it feels truly strange to be away from home. This will be the first time in my life that I'm not there to honor this day with my New York City community. On this day, 14 years ago, our community came together under a tragic and shocking circumstance. While people could've ran from the burning building, pushing their peers out of the way, many actually stayed to help rescue their fellow New Yorkers and many of them lost their lives. To the heroes of that day and of the days following, your unwarranted sacrifices, often for complete strangers, are impossible to repay. From the aforementioned brave coworkers to the firemen and volunteers who lifted our broken community to the memorial committee who created a structure of universally patriotic significance. So much has been done in lieu of 9/11, and I have grown up witnessing the process. So it's really weird to not be there right now: walking to the bus with my brother and going to the Poly memorial garden in silence. I am there in spirit🇺🇸

me.message: To all who know this about me (and to those who don't), I am saying goodbye to a significant part of my life today. Tomorrow, not only do I leave home behind, but also an addiction. To all my friends and peers reading this (or skimming), please understand that this is what I have to do. I have to make a promise to myself and those around me that I am making a change. To those of you who chew tobacco or have family or friends who do, this is for you. About a year and a half ago, I tried Skoal wintergreen smokeless tobacco pouches. Chewing tobacco (or dip) culture in baseball declined a few decades ago, only to surge back into popularity over the past 15 years. The highest levels of the game have made significant effort to limit the use of chew or dip and to educate about the adverse effects and promote alternatives such as gum, sunflower seeds and herbal snuff. After all of these endeavors, dip is still at large in the game of baseball and throughout other sports such as football and hockey. For me, I was hooked right away. I started dipping 3, 4, and sometimes five times a day. I remember days down south at baseball tournaments where I did it so much I couldn't keep track. It was mindless. To all the smokers and dippers out there, think about how many times nicotine has hypnotized you into feeding the addiction. I am someone who likes to feel in control, but I uncharacteristically let myself lose control multiple times a day. When my parents found out last summer, it was a mess. I had never seen my dad truly ashamed in me until that day. I told them that I was addicted and promised to stop. That didn't go well. After a month of abstaining, I relapsed. I continued to use covertly for several months. Without any of my family knowing, there was very little guilt, so it made it easier for me to make bad decisions. These scenarios continued over the following year. I've never seen so many concerned family members and friends, and I've never seen my mother cry as much as she did. I didn't really understand why until today as I sat in an oral surgeon's office. He told me I'm probably fine, but that I have a small white patch on the inside of my gum called leukoplakia. Most dippers develop these, but some can be pre-cancerous or cancerous. As soon as I heard that, I said "I'm done". That was it. Months of therapy, tears and begging. All it took was some cold hard facts, and the knowledge that a pointless habit has left a potentially lethal mark on me. I love baseball. I love country music. I love Diet Mountain Dew. I really loved dip. Despite my urban upbringing, baseball turns me into quite the hick. While all those other hobbies are fun, dip is certainly not worth it. I do not intend to get buried by my parents and brother for something so trivial and pointless. Fuck that. I intend to live a long life. I am leaving for one of the best universities in the world tomorrow morning, and I don't want to worry about getting mouth cancer while I'm at it. So parents, don't just discourage smoking, make sure to do the same for smokeless (especially for those of you with young boys). I have not and will never pick up a cigarette (my grandmother smoked 2 packs a day for 55 years, and I begged her to stop until she did), but I somehow thought chewing carcinogens was cool. God knows where I got that logic, but I'm glad I realize how stupid I was. To boys considering trying dip, don't. It's fun, but you will smell bad, your teeth will look gross and most of your girlfriends will break up with you. I'm done. I just wish I never started. And to all the Poly teachers trying to snipe kids in the locker room, tough luck ;)

me.message: The riots in Baltimore are understandable, but not justified. A black community in Baltimore that was once falsely perceived as violent is just proving everyone right, and ruining it for all of the outstanding people of color in the United States. Not to mention that the rioters are destroying their own community, what is that going to do? 400 years of social and legal oppression is beyond frustrating, but responding with violence can only aggravate the wound. I could never share the anger of the black population, but this is just common sense. I want equal opportunity to happen, but the riots in Baltimore only puts Black America in a deeper hole. Nobody knows the exact right way to fix racial inequality in America, but it is certainly not burning down the city you were raised in.

me.message:
Friends, 
Please fight for the LGBT community in sports!
Go to http://www.athleteally.org/action/fairness-final-four/ and sign a petition to fight against discrimination.
The Governor of Indiana has signed a law that makes it legal to discriminate against the LGBT community in the Hoosier state, a place that's home to the NCAA and to major sporting events every year.Did you know that Indiana is the host state to the Final Four, the NFL Combine, the USA P&G Gymnastics Championship, the USA Olympic Diving Trials, the Big Ten Football Championship and more?
Now, athletes, coaches, and fans that attend these events, including the 80,000 fans arriving next week for the Final Four, can be turned away and disrespected because of who they are. 
That's why we've launched the #Final4Fairness Campaign with the help of Lambda Legal. We must bring this injustice to the forefront of the Final Four. The time is NOW.
Sports are a part of Indiana's fabric, but the values we hold true in athletics are compromised on Hoosier soil.
Join the #Final4Fairness Campaign and help us tell Indiana and every other state that discrimination is unacceptable on the court and under the law.

All I can say is that it has definitely made me more aware of the language that I use. I have had multiple people come up to me and say the same thing. By signing the pledge, you are subconsciously making a commitment to being more mindful about how you speak, and how you respond to anti-LGBT language for your friends and peers. No amount of money can solve this issue. All we can do is band together and be the best we can be. Poly and all high schools around the country should be following in Hudson's footsteps. Mr. Broussard, I really respected you as a quality sports analyst, but now you can get fired and go to hell, the way you think a homosexual man should, but really, it is you who will. Seriously, these remarks were not yours to make, and not anyone else's to make either. Just lets Collins do what he wants to do, and what makes him happy, what he did was brave. People like Chris Broussard are the reason that we aren't making any progress as an accepting country and world. A respect, and well known sports figure yet again shows that our world is screwed up, and people that don't interpret the bible for what it is can just shove it. I think everyone's opinion should be valued, with exception this opinion, because it is just ridiculous. It does not concern anyone, it does not concern God and it most certainly does not concern Chris Broussard. God did not create a world so that there could be hatred; he created love, tolerance and acceptance, and how we choose to interpret things like this dictates our progress as global citizens and people. I may be guilty of throwing around the "gay" "homo" "faggot" when it is not ever necessary, and that was not how I was raised so I screwed up, but we need to get better, people, much better.

A poem I wrote a while back. Thought it was fitting after tonights events. No stupid criticism in the comments though, please. Go blue. We found our real mirage, or almost did. #onedayonegame

Mirage

You thought you found it.
You thought you found it again. 
And again.
And again.
A man always strives to find out what he's best at.
What's best for him. 
He's thinks he found it.
Nope.
Slipped away.
Lost in the desert like before.
Trying to find his true home.
What that home means is distinct for every man.
In time, he will know.
He will find home
Or at least, what he thinks is home.
Home can be finding passion.
Home can be reconnecting with friends you care about.
Home can be love.
But just as you think you see it, you realize it isn't real.
Just the deception of a desert mirage. 
You rub your eyes, and keep walking.
Until you stumble upon another mirage.
This continues until the mirage you stumbled upon doesn't go away.
Living the dream, so to speak.

My condolences to those children and teachers who lost their lives in Newton Connecticut. There are some crazy people out there. This is another reason (including the recent James Holmes case, and Jared Loughner a bit before that) why the 2nd amendment is bullshit. I know taking it away would upset a lot of redneck hillbillies out there, but there can't be so many lethal weapons just floating around. Look at the UK, for example, who only lost a couple hundred people due to murder-per year, while our country lost tens of thousand of people... Guess what? UK doesn't let crazy people (or people who have crazy sons) bear arms, and the statistics show. This is not only a sad time, but it's a lesson for our country to learn from its mistakes.

Obama the takes the leadddd!!!

This election is really gonna come down to 3 swing states I think: Florida, Pennsylvania and Ohio. This is gonna be stressful. First of all, I'd like to acknowledge that I know my opinion doesn't mean shit because first of all, I can't vote, and second of all, New York's not even close. However, if it did, I fully support Obama not because I love him, because I don't think he did a great job in his first term, but unlike Mr. Romney, he is able to address the social issues *cough*Gay Marriage, Abortion, Separation between church and state*cough*. Yes, Obama increased the deficit, but he had to get us out of a war we should have never taken part in (Iraq), we are in the worst financial position since the depression and our right-wing congress gave him very little help so a lot of his ideas were shut down. I can't say too much about "Obamacare" because I am not too well informed on every detail, but I guess some people don't like it very much, but it's better than having Romney, who will lower taxes for the rich and raise taxes on the middle class, and that makes very little sense. Just because Romney is too selfish to give up a portion of his income despite the fact that he has enough money to wipe his ass with sheets of gold, his avid supporter Donald Trump can also resonate with that as he is so greedy, that he would probably would take up Stephen Colbert's 1 million dollar offer to dip his balls in Trump's mouth. I happen to like neither, but with Romney's social plan, and his general sense of morality, I don't see how anybody could vote for him, I mean, no offense intended to his supporters, but I personally think the fact that a really significant portion of our country supports him over Obama is really just a joke. Larry, I know you're gonna wanna comment on this and tell me how I am wrong so I'll give you the green light on that front ;).

Sorry guys :( 
They Hurt Her
Carmen was 17 years old when her parents decided to move to India. Her father had lost his job and the only way he could find new employment was by moving to a new state the relocation caused a lot of problems for Carmen. She had to leave her friends behind and attend a whole new school in Indiana. Carmen had a hard time making friends when she changed schools. It was the middle of the school year and most of the students had no interest in befriending the new girl. Initially, she spent many days alone, walking from class to class without speaking to anyone, but she eventually started hanging around with a group of five other girls. Carmen thought these girls were her friends, but it wasn’t long before she discovered that they had been talking about her behind her back and spreading vile rumors.

When she confronted them, the girls turned on her and began bullying her every day, making her life a misery. They started out calling her names, but then the bullying got much worse. One day, she left her school books in the classroom at break time. When shereturned, she found someone had taken a sharpie and written dirty words all over her books. Another day, she opened her bag and discovered someone had poured yoghurt all over the insides. Sometimes, she would come to school and find her locker had been vandalized. The final straw came when she put on her coat at recess and found that someone had stuffed dog poop in her pockets.

There and then, Carmen decided that she couldn’t take the bullying any longer. She planned to stay behind, that evening, after school, and tell her teacher what had been happening. Unfortunately, her decision came too late to save her life.

After lunch, her teacher announced that the school was holding a fire drill. When the alarm sounded, Carmen and the other students filed out of the classroom and assembled in the yard outside. As the teachers read out the roll call, the gang of five girls decided that this was a great opportunity to embarrass Carmen in front of the whole school during the fire drill. They moved over to where Carmen was standing, near a sewer drain, and began crowding the poorgirl, getting in her face and nudging her towards the open manhole.

They pushed her and she tripped over and fell head-first down the manhole. When they saw her falling, the girls started giggling and when Carmen’s name was called out, they shouted "She’s down in the sewer!"

All of the other students began laughing. But when the teachers looked down the manhole and saw Carmen’s body lying at the bottom in the muck and the poop, the laughter abruptly stopped. Her head was twisted around at an odd angle and her face was covered in blood. Worse still, she wasn’t moving. There was nothing any of the teachers could do for her. Carmen was dead. When the police arrived and went down into the sewer, they determined that she had broken her neck. Her face had been torn off when she hit the ladder on the way down and her neck snapped when she landed on her head on the concrete at the bottom.

The police hauled Carmen’s body out of the sewer and sent her to the mortuary. Everyone had to stay behind after school while the police questioned all of Carmen’s classmates. The five girlslied to the police, saying they had witnessed Carmen falling down the sewer. The police believed the girls and Carmen Winstead’s death was ruled an accident and the case was closed. Everyone thought that was the last they would hear of Carmen Winstead, but they were wrong.

Months later, Carmen’s classmates began receiving strange e-mails on their MySpaces. The e-mails were titled "They Pushed Her" and claimed that Carmen hadn’t really fallen down the sewer, she had been pushed. The e-mails also warned that the guilty people should own up and take responsibility for their crime. If they didn’t there would be horrible consequences. Most people dismissed the e-mails as a hoax, but others were not so sure.

A few days later, one of the girls who pushed Carmen down the sewer was at home taking a shower, when she heard a strange cackling laugh. It seemed to be coming from the drain. The girl started to freak out and ran out of the bathroom. That night, the girl said goodnight to her mom and went to sleep. Five hours later, her mom was awoken in the middle of the night, by a loudnoise that resounded throughout the house. She ran into her daughter’s room, only to find it empty. There was no trace of the girl. The worried mother called the police and when they arrived, they conducted a search of the area. Eventually, they discovered the girl’s grisly remains.

Her corpse was lying in the sewer, covered in muck and poop. Her neck was broken and her face missing. It had been completely torn off. One by one, all of the girls who pushed Carmen that day were found dead. They had all been killed in exactly the same way and were all found at exactly the same spot. In the sewer at the bottom of the same uncovered manhole where Carmen had met her doom. But the killing didn’t stop there. More and more of Carmen’s former classmates were found dead. It seemed that anyone who didn’t believe that Carmen had been pushed, was eventually found down in the sewer with their necks broken and their faces torn off.

They say that Carmen’s ghost is still on the rampage, hunting down anyone who doesn’t believe herstory. According to the legend, Carmen will get you, whetherit’s from a toilet, a shower, a sink or a drain. When you go to sleep, you’ll wake up in the sewer, in complete darkness, paralyzed, unable to move, hearing cackling laughter all around you. Then, as you scream in horror, Carmen will come and tear your face off.

So be careful who you bully, because you just might find yourself on the receiving end of the curse of Carmen Winstead.

FACT: About two months later, 16-year-old David Gregory read this post and didn't repost it. When he went to take a shower, he heard laughter, started freaking out, and ran to his computer to repost it. He said goodnight to his mom and went to sleep, but five hours later, his mom woke up in the middle of the night from a loud noise and David was gone. A few hours later, the police found him in the sewer, with a broken neck and the skin on his face peeled off.

Even Google her name - you'll find this to be true.

If you don't repost this saying "They hurt her," then Carmen will get you, either from a sewer, the toilet, the shower

I'm raising money for Parkinson's disease because it is very important to me and I need your help. My grandfather has Parkinson's and so does a close family friend of mine. I have witnessed the effects that is has on my grandpa and it really makes me sad that there is no way to stop it, and he is stuck this way as long as there is no cure. I really need my friends, your friends and their friends to donate money to my cause. Whether you donate $5 or $5,000, any amount of money is going to make a difference. I have named my cause Pogo for Parkinson's because I am lucky to have the physical ability to pogo stick, and I want all my supporters to understand my dedication to the cause. I am going to pogo stick thousands of times around town with family members and friends, raising money along the way. If most of you can donate even a little money to my cause, we can make a big difference in the fight. Tell your friends on Facebook and elsewhere about my cause and please ask them to donate. This is an important fight and it's important that we all do something about it! Thanks in advance for your support :-)
